title: Maria - Diabetes Follow-Up
learning_objectives: Practice continuity in chronic disease management
Explore how life changes affect disease management
Celebrate small wins while addressing ongoing barriers
Adjust treatment plans based on real-world results
Apply MAAS follow-up item adaptations in complex social context

patient.name: Maria Santos
patient.occupation: Cleaner at office building (part-time) + kitchen helper at restaurant (part-time)
patient.language_fluency: fluent (Dutch as second language, Portuguese first)
patient.appearance: Looks slightly less tired than last time. Still in work clothes but seems a bit more relaxed. Made effort to come on time.

personality.emotional_state: Cautiously hopeful about some things, worried about new problems at home. More trusting because felt heard last time.
personality.notes: Built some trust at last visit. More willing to share struggles. However, has a new worry about her son that she's hesitant to bring up. Still proud and doesn't want to complain.

previous_consultation.what_was_discussed: Maria's poorly controlled diabetes, identified multiple social barriers (eigen risico, work schedule, food access, transportation). Explored her fears about complications. Discussed realistic strategies.
what_was_recommended: Referral to maatschappelijk werk (social work) for financial support
Metformin dose increased to 850mg twice daily
Start gliclazide—pharmacy to work out eigen risico payment plan
Simple dietary changes: portion control, reduce sugary drinks
previous_consultation.what_patient_understood: Doctor understood my situation. Going to get help with the money problems. New medication. Need to watch what I eat but doesn't have to be perfect.
previous_consultation.follow_up_instructions: Return in 6 weeks to see how things are going. Come sooner if feet get worse or any new problems.

symptom_evolution.description: Feet hurt less. Less thirsty. Has more energy—not a lot, but better than before. Still tired but not as exhausted.

medications.details: Taking metformin consistently now—pharmacy set up automatic delivery. Gliclazide: took it for first 4 weeks, then ran out and couldn't refill immediately (2-week gap). Back on it now.
medications.barriers: Still some confusion about when to take gliclazide, missed pharmacy delivery once

lifestyle_recommendations.details: Stopped drinking sweet coffee at work. Tries to have smaller portions. Walking a bit more—gets off bus one stop earlier when weather is okay. Hasn't been able to do more.
lifestyle_recommendations.barriers: No time or energy for structured exercise. Food choices still limited by budget and availability.

tests_completed.details: Went to diabetesverpleegkundige twice (helpful). Fundoscopy: made appointment but had to reschedule (work conflict).

referrals_attended.details: Saw diabetesverpleegkundige twice—very helpful. Saw maatschappelijk werker once—applied for help with eigen risico. Fundoscopy rescheduled.

patient_experience.what_patient_researched: Looked up diabetes on Portuguese health website. Sister sent her information about diabetes diet.
new_concerns: Son (14) is having trouble at school—skipping classes, bad grades, won't talk to her
Worried the stress is affecting her health
Wondering if son's behavior could be related to her health or their situation
Eye appointment got rescheduled—worried about what they might find
patient_experience.who_patient_talked_to: Sister more supportive since last visit. Diabetesverpleegkundige was kind and helpful. Son not talking.
patient_experience.coping: Trying to focus on one thing at a time. Church when she can. Talking to sister helps.

tests.Feet_exam: No ulcers, sensation still reduced but no deterioration

referral_reports.diabetesverpleegkundige: Patient engaged well. Set up glucose monitoring at home. Discussed medication timing. Addressed foot care. Will continue seeing her monthly.
referral_reports.maatschappelijk_werk: Application submitted for eigen risico compensation via gemeente. Expected decision in 4 weeks. Also discussed Voedselbank if needed.

results.clinical_interpretation: Modest improvement in glucose control with better medication adherence. Social interventions partially successful. New psychosocial stressor (son's problems) may affect ongoing management.
results.how_to_explain: Good news: your blood sugar is better—the changes you made are working. Your feet are stable. Still work to do, but you're on the right track. I also want to hear how things are at home.

prognosis.expected_course: With continued adherence and support, diabetes can be stabilized. Complications progression can be slowed or halted.
factors_favoring_recovery: Social support being put in place
prognosis.what_patient_should_expect: Continued gradual improvement if she can keep up with medications. HbA1c should be better at 3-month check.
prognosis.when_to_worry: Foot wounds, sudden vision changes, severe symptoms

today.stated_reason: Here for my diabetes check-up. To see how things are going.
today.real_reason: Wants validation that she's doing okay. Also worried about her son but unsure if she should bring it up at a medical appointment.
today.hidden_agenda: Hoping the doctor will ask about how she's doing generally, not just the diabetes. Needs someone to tell her she's not failing.

new_concerns: Missed eye appointment—worried about what's wrong with her eyes

interval_emotions.what_patient_felt: Mixed: proud of small improvements, worried about son, exhausted but hopeful, grateful for help but still struggling
interval_emotions.unresolved_from_last_time: Still worried about ending up like her aunt. Still financially stressed though help is coming.

complaint.chief_complaint: Here for my diabetes check-up. Things are a bit better, I think.

heuristic_1_nature.description: Foot pain still there but less intense. Fatigue improved but still present.
heuristic_1_nature.quality: Same burning in feet but milder. Tiredness more manageable.

heuristic_2_time_intensity.onset_description: Started noticing less thirst after about 2 weeks on the new medication
heuristic_2_time_intensity.duration: Foot pain still at end of day but doesn't keep her up at night anymore

heuristic_3_modifiers.associated_activities: Work still demanding but managing better

ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_ideas: Thinks the medication is helping. Wonders if stress with her son is making things worse.
ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_concerns: Worried about her son. Worried she missed the eye appointment—what if something is wrong? Still scared about complications.
ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_expectations: Wants to hear she's doing okay. Wants to reschedule the eye appointment. Maybe wants to talk about her son if there's space.

medications: Gliclazide 30mg daily (had 2-week gap, now back on)
family_history: Father: died of heart attack at 58

social_history.living_situation: Flat with 2 children—10-year-old daughter doing well, 14-year-old son struggling
social_history.support_system: Sister more involved now, mother in Portugal

present: Diabetes still not at target (though improving)
red_flags.notes: Clinical trajectory positive. New psychosocial stressor (son) needs attention—may affect Maria's ability to maintain improvements.

diagnosis.working_diagnosis: Type 2 diabetes mellitus—improving control with ongoing management challenges and new psychosocial stressor

simulation_guidance.initial_presentation: Comes in looking a bit brighter than last time. Still in work clothes but made effort to be on time. Says 'I came for my check-up. I think things are a bit better?' Tone is hopeful but seeking validation.

if_asked_directly: Ran out of gliclazide for two weeks
Had to reschedule the eye appointment
Still hard to eat healthy on budget
Saw the social worker—waiting for decision
if_asked_sensitively: Worried about her son—he's skipping school, won't talk to her
Stress with her son is affecting her sleep and eating
Wonders if family stress is making diabetes harder to control
Scared what they'll find at eye check
Sometimes feels like she's failing as a mother
will_not_share: Won't bring up son unless asked about home life or stress
Won't admit how much the son situation is affecting her without empathic opening
Won't ask for help with son directly—doesn't know if it's appropriate

emotional_moments: When doctor acknowledges her progress (relief, maybe tears)
When asked about what's hard or stressful at home (son)
When discussing her son's problems (guilt, worry)
If doctor connects her stress to her health
If doctor offers help for son's situation
guardrails: More open than first visit but still reserved about family problems
Seeking validation—respond positively if doctor notices improvement
Become withdrawn if doctor only focuses on what's not perfect
Son's situation is sensitive—don't bring up unless space is created

what_patient_remembers: Need to watch the sugary drinks
what_patient_forgot: What exactly the diabetesverpleegkundige said about timing
When HbA1c check is supposed to happen

if_asked_sensitively: Struggled to stay on track when stressed about son
Sometimes too tired to cook properly
will_not_volunteer: The 2-week medication gap happened during worst week with son

if_asked_sensitively: Sometimes feels like she's failing at everything

key_items: A.2 — Bridging past and present agenda
A.5 — Interval exploration (what happened since last visit)
B.5 — Responds to emotions and concerns (validating progress)
2.13 — Ongoing exploration of social circumstances (son's problems)
maas_focus.learning_notes: This follow-up case teaches continuity in chronic disease management with complex social factors. Key skills: (1) Bridge from previous visit using Five Elements, (2) Celebrate progress without dismissing ongoing challenges, (3) Explore what's changed—including NEW stressors not present before, (4) Recognize that family problems affect patient's health and self-management. The hidden agenda (son's problems) tests whether student creates space for the whole person, not just the disease. Best students will ask about home life and connect stress to diabetes management.

items: A.5 (interval exploration) — 'How have the last six weeks been?'
B.5/B.7 (validation) — 'It sounds like you've worked hard at this'
